text.1:
Surah al-Fatihah begins with the Basmalah

There are several scholarly opinions regarding the Basmalah found at the beginning of Surah Al-Fatihah. Among these opinions, the most well-known are:

1. The Basmalah is a separate verse, revealed by Allah to be the heading of each surah and a separator between one surah and another. Thus, it is not a verse from al-Fatihah or from any other surah that begins with the Basmalah. This is the opinion of Imam Malik along with the experts in *qira'ah* and *fuqaha* (experts in jurisprudence) of Medina, Basra, and Syria, as well as the opinion of Imam Abu Hanifah and his followers. Therefore, according to Imam Abu Hanifah, the Basmalah is not recited loudly in prayer, and Imam Malik does not recite the Basmalah at all.

Hadith of the Prophet saw:

From Anas bin Malik, he said, "I prayed behind the Prophet saw, Abu Bakr, Umar, and Usman. They began with *al-hamdulillahi rabbil 'alamin*, without mentioning *Bismillahirrahmanirrahim* at the beginning of the recitation, nor at the end." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim).

2. The Basmalah is one of the verses of al-Fatihah, and in Surah an-Naml/27:30, /27:30) which begins with the Basmalah. This is the opinion of Imam Syafi'i along with the experts in *qira'ah* of Mecca and Kufa. Therefore, according to them, the Basmalah is recited loudly in prayer (*jahar*). The evidence that supports this includes the Hadith of the Prophet saw:

From Ibn 'Abbas, he said, the Messenger of Allah saw recited *Bismillahirrahmanirrahim* loudly. (Narrated by al-Hakim in al-Mustadrak and according to him, this hadith is *sahih* - authentic).

From Ummu Salamah, she said, the Messenger of Allah saw paused repeatedly in his recitation: *Bismillahirrahmanirrahim, al-hamdulillahi Rabbil- 'alamin, ar-Rahmanir-rahim, Maliki Yaumid-din*. (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Daud, Ibn Khuzaimah, and al-Hakim. According to ad-Daruqutni, the *sanad* of this hadith is *sahih*).

Abu Hurairah also prayed and recited the basmalah loudly. After finishing the prayer, he said, "I am the one whose prayer is most similar to the Messenger of Allah." Muawiyah also once prayed in Medina without reciting the basmalah loudly. He was protested by the other companions who were present there. Finally, in the next prayer, Muawiyah recited the basmalah loudly.

If we consider that the companions of the Messenger of Allah saw agreed to write the Basmalah at the beginning of each surah of the Qur'an, except for Surah at-Taubah (because from the beginning it was not revealed with the Basmalah), and that the Messenger of Allah saw forbade writing anything that was not the Qur'an so that it would not be mixed with the Qur'an, so they did not write 'amin at the end of Surah al-Fatihah, then the Basmalah is one of the verses of the Qur'an. In other words, the "basmalahs" found in the Qur'an are verses of the Qur'an, regardless of whether they are one verse from al-Fatihah or from another surah that begins with the Basmalah or not.

As mentioned above, Surah al-Fatihah consists of seven verses. Those who believe that the Basmalah is not included as one of the verses of al-Fatihah consider:

to be one of the verses, thus the verses of al-Fatihah remain seven.

"In the name of Allah" means "In the name of Allah, I recite or I begin." It is as if the Prophet said, "I recite this surah by mentioning the name of Allah, not by mentioning my own name, because it is a revelation from God, not from myself." So the Basmalah here implies that the Qur'an is a revelation from Allah, not a composition of Muhammad saw, and Muhammad is only a Messenger of Allah who is commanded to convey the Qur'an to mankind.

Meaning of the word Allah

Allah is the name for the Essence that exists by itself (*wajibul-wujud*). The word "Allah" is only used by the Arabs for the true God, who has the right to be worshipped, who has the attributes of perfection. They do not use that word for their other gods or deities.

Wisdom of Reciting the Basmalah

A person who always recites the Basmalah before doing an important task means that he always remembers Allah in every task he does. Thus, he will carry out the task by always paying attention to Allah's norms and not harming others. As a result, the work he does will bear fruit as an *ukhrawi* (related to the afterlife) deed.

A Muslim is commanded to recite the Basmalah when doing something good. This is to remind him that what is being done is because of Allah's command, or because He has permitted it. So, for Allah, he does the work and to Him, he asks for help so that the work is carried out well and successfully.

The Prophet saw said:

"Every important task that is not started by mentioning the Basmalah is truncated (lacking in blessing)." (Narrated by Abdul-Qadir ar-Rahawi).

The Arabs before Islam did something by mentioning al-Lata and al-'Uzza, the names of their idols. Therefore, Allah taught the followers of the Islamic religion who had monotheized Him, that they should do something by mentioning the name of Allah.
text.2:
In the verse above, Allah begins His word by mentioning "Basmalah" to teach His servants to begin a good deed by mentioning basmalah, as a statement that he is doing that deed for Allah and to Him he asks for help and blessings. Thus, in this verse, Allah teaches His servants to always praise Him.

*Al-hamdu* means praise, because of the goodness given by the one being praised, or because of a virtuous quality that he possesses. All the blessings that have been felt and obtained in this universe are from Allah, because He is the source of all blessings. Only Allah possesses perfect attributes. Therefore, only Allah is worthy of praise. A person who says *al-hamdu lillah* not only acknowledges that praise is for Allah alone, but with his utterance, he praises Allah.

*Rabb* means owner, manager, and maintainer. It contains the meaning of educating, which is conveying something to a perfect state gradually.

*'Alamin* means all the worlds, that is, all types of creatures. The worlds are of various types, namely the plant world, the animal world, the human world, the material world, the subtle world, for example, angels, jinn, and other worlds. Some *mufasir* (commentators) restrict *'alamin* in this verse to Allah's creatures who have reason, namely humans, angels, and jinn. But this narrows the meaning of the word, which is actually very broad.

Thus, Allah is the Educator of all the worlds, there is nothing from Allah's creation that is free from His education. God educates His creatures with the broadest meaning of that word. As an educator, He grows, protects, gives power (energy) and weapons to that creature, for the perfection of their respective lives.

Whoever pays attention to the journey of the stars, investigates the life of plants and animals in the sea and on land, studies the growth of humans from their mother's womb to childhood, then becomes a perfect human being, will know that there is nothing from Allah's creation that is free from His protection, maintenance, care, and *inayah* (divine providence).
text.3:
In the second verse above, Allah swt explains that He is the Lord of all the worlds. Therefore, to remind His servants of the manifold blessings and favors that He has bestowed, as well as His eternal nature and love, He repeats the mention of ar-Rahman ar-Rahim. This is intended to erase from the minds of servants the image of tyranny and oppression, like that of kings who are lords and act arbitrarily.

Allah reminds us in this verse that Allah's divine nature towards His servants is not one of tyranny and oppression, but is based on love and compassion. Thus, humans will love their Lord and worship Allah with a safe and peaceful heart, free from fear and anxiety. Indeed, they will learn from Allah's attributes. They will base their interactions and behavior towards their fellow humans, or towards those under their leadership, even towards animals that cannot speak, on that quality of love and compassion. For it is in this way that humans will receive mercy and grace from their Lord.

The Messenger of Allah said:

Allah only has mercy on His merciful servants. (Narrated by at-Tabrani)

Those who are merciful will be shown mercy by Allah, the Rahman Tabaraka wa Ta'ala. (Therefore) have mercy on all creatures on earth, and all creatures in the heavens will have mercy on you all. (Narrated by Ahmad, Abu Dawud at-Tirmidzi and al-Hakim).

The Messenger of Allah said:

"Whoever shows mercy, even to a sparrow that is slaughtered, Allah will have mercy on him on the Day of Judgment." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

The meaning of the third hadith is to use proper rules and procedures when slaughtering a bird, for example, using a sharp knife. It can also be understood from the order of the words ar-Rahman, ar-Rahim, that Allah's protection, preservation, and care for the entire universe is not because He expects something from the universe, but solely because of His mercy and compassion.

It may occur to some people, why does Allah create rules and laws, and punish those who violate them? This thought will disappear when it is known that the rules and laws, as well as the punishment in the afterlife or in this world that Allah makes for His servants who violate them, are not contrary to Allah's attributes of being the Most Compassionate and Most Merciful, because the rules and laws are a mercy from Allah for the good of mankind itself. Likewise, Allah's punishment for His servants who violate the rules and laws is in accordance with His justice.
text.4:
After Allah mentioned some of His attributes, namely: Lord of all the worlds, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, He followed it by mentioning another of His attributes, namely "Master of the Day of Judgment." The mention of this verse is intended so that Allah's power over this universe does not stop only in this world, but continues until the Hereafter.

There are two kinds of readings regarding Malik. First, by lengthening the *ma*, and second by shortening it. According to the first reading, Malik means "The Owner" (The Possessor). While according to the second reading, it means "King." Both readings are correct.

Whether according to the first reading or the second reading, the meaning of "powerful" and acting fully can be understood from the word. That is why it is translated as "The Master." "Yaum" means day, but what is meant here is time absolutely.

Ad-din has many meanings, including: (1) calculation, (2) reward, retribution, (3) obedient, (4) submissive, and (5) sharia, religion. What is in line here is the meaning of "retribution." So, *Maliki yaumiddin* means "Allah is the One who is in control and who can act fully towards all His creatures on the Day of Judgment."

Actually, on the Day of Judgment many things happen, namely the Resurrection, the gathering, the reckoning, the retribution, but only the retribution is mentioned by Allah here, because that is the most important thing. The others, for example the Resurrection, the gathering and so on, are the introduction to the retribution, especially for *targib* and *tarhib* (encouraging and intimidating), the mention of "Day of Judgment" is more appropriate.

The Hereafter According to Reason (Philosophy)

Belief in the existence of the Hereafter, on which day there will be a reckoning of human actions during his lifetime and a corresponding retribution, is a belief that is in accordance with reason. Therefore, the existence of another life, after life in this world, is not only determined by religion, but also indicated by reason.

Someone who wants to think will certainly feel that life in this world is not perfect, it needs to be connected with another life. How many people who have been persecuted in this world have returned to *rahmatullah* before getting justice. How many people who have made small or large contributions have not received appreciation for their services. How many people have tried, squeezed sweat, worked hard, but have not had time to feel the fruits of their efforts. Conversely, how many criminals, persecutors, troublemakers, who cannot be reached by the courts in this world. Especially if the person who commits the crime or persecution is a powerful person as a king, official and others. So, even if the crime and persecution have chained the entire nation, no one will sue him, instead he will continue to be worshiped and respected. So, where will justice be found, if there is no higher court later, the Court of Allah on the Day of Judgment?

Therefore, thinkers from ancient times have come to believe in the existence of the Hereafter, solely through thinking, including Pythagoras. This philosopher argues that life in this world is a provision for eternal life in the Hereafter. Therefore, from the world, people should be prepared for eternal life. Socrates, Plato and Aristotle argued, "A good soul will feel pleasure and delight in the Hereafter, but not material pleasure, because material pleasure is limited and brings boredom and boredom. Only spiritual pleasure, no matter how much and how long, does not cause boredom and boredom."

The Belief of Arab Society Before Islam about the Hereafter

Among the Arab society before Islam there were several thinkers and poets who believed in the existence of the Hereafter, such as Zuhair bin Abi Sulma who died a year before the Prophet Muhammad saw was sent by Allah as a messenger.

There were also some of them who did not believe in the existence of the Hereafter. Listen to what one of their poets said: "Life, then death, then resurrection again, that's a fairy tale, O so-and-so." Therefore, the religion of Islam came, bringing certainty about the existence of the Hereafter. On that day, all the actions that humans have done during their lives will be reckoned, big or small. Allah says:

(7) So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, (8) And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it. (az-Zalzalah/99: 7-8)

There are not a few verses in the Al-Qur'an that explain that among them many did not believe in the existence of the Hereafter; life is only in the world, after that it is finished (al-An'am/6: 29; al-Mu'minun/23: 37). They said, when a father dies, then a child is born, when a nation is destroyed, then another nation comes. They do not believe that after death humans will still live again (Hud/11: 7; al-Isra'/17: 49) and many more similar verses that describe such a stance. In the history of thought it is recorded that since ancient times there have been many such assumptions.
text.5:
In the previous verses, four attributes of Allah were mentioned: the Educator of the entire universe, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, and the Master of the Day of Judgment. These attributes are those of perfection that only Allah possesses. Therefore, in this verse, Allah teaches His servants that only Allah is worthy of worship, and only to Him should humans seek help, and that His servants must declare this.

Iyyaka (only to You). Iyyaka is a pronoun for the second person in the accusative case because it is a maf'ul bih (object). In Arabic grammar, the maf'ul bih must come after the fi'il (verb) and fa'il (subject). If what should be said later is placed first, in Balaghah (rhetoric) it indicates qasr, which is a restriction that can be interpreted as "only." So the meaning of this verse is "Only to You do we worship, and only to You do we seek help."

Iyyaka in this verse is repeated twice, the purpose of which is to emphasize that worship and isti'anah (seeking help) are each specifically directed to Allah and to achieve the pleasure of munajat (speaking) with Allah. Because for a servant of Allah who worships with all his soul and body, there is nothing more pleasant and delicious than communicating with Allah.

It is also good to know that using iyyaka means directing the conversation to Allah, with the intention of remembering Allah SWT, as if we are in His presence, and to Him the conversation is directed with khusyuk (humility) and tawaduk (submission). It's as if we are saying:

"O Allah, the Being who is wajibul wujud (necessary existence), Who is characterized by all the attributes of perfection, Who guards and maintains the entire universe, Who bestows His grace and blessings manifold, Who is in control on the Day of Judgment, You alone do we worship, and to You alone do we ask for help, because only You are worthy of worship, and only You can help us."

In this way, a person will be more khusyuk in worshiping Allah and the greatness of the one being worshiped will be more clearly depicted. This is what the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) meant by his saying:

"You worship Allah as if you see Him (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from 'Umar bin al-Khatthab)."

Because Surah al-Fatihah contains verses of munajat (speaking) with Allah according to the method that has been explained, this is the secret why it is obligatory to recite it in every rakaat in prayer, because its soul is munajat, by facing oneself and focusing remembrance on Allah.

Na'budu in this verse is mentioned before nasta'inu, because worshiping Allah is a human obligation to his Lord. But help from Allah to His servants is the right of that servant. So Allah teaches His servants to fulfill their obligations first, before they demand their rights.

Seeing the words na'budu and nasta'inu (we worship, we ask for help), not a'budu and asta'inu (I worship and I ask for help) is to show the weakness of humans, it is not appropriate for humans to put themselves forward alone in worshiping and asking for help from Allah. As if the fulfillment of the obligation to worship and the request for help from Allah is not yet perfect, unless it is done together.

The Position of Tawhid in Worship and Vice Versa

Ibadah (worship) in terms of terminology is all words, deeds and thoughts that aim to seek the pleasure of Allah. The meaning of "ibadah" as mentioned above is to submit and surrender to Allah, which is caused by the awareness that Allah created this universe, Who grows, Who develops, Who guards and maintains and Who brings it from one state to another, until its perfection is achieved.

In short, ibadah arises from a feeling of tawhid (monotheism). Therefore, people who like to think about the state of this universe, who pay attention to the movement of the stars, the life of plants, animals and humans, even those who want to pay attention to themselves, are sure that behind the visible realm there is a hidden Essence that controls this universe, which is characterized by all the attributes of perfection, namely He is the Almighty, the Most Gracious, the All-Knowing and so on. Then there grows in his heart a feeling of gratitude and indebtedness to the Almighty, the Most Gracious and the All-Knowing Essence.

This feeling moves his lips to utter praises, and encourages his soul and body to worship and humble himself to Allah the Almighty as an expression of gratitude and repayment of kindness to Him. But there are also people who do not want to think, and furthermore are not aware of the greatness and power of Allah, often forgetting Him. Therefore, every religion prescribes various kinds of ibadah, the purpose of which is to remind humans of the greatness and power of Allah. With this explanation, it can be seen that tawhid and ibadah influence each other, in the sense that tawhid fosters ibadah, and ibadah cultivates tawhid.

The Influence of Ibadah on the Human Soul

Every ibadah that is carried out because it is driven by the feelings mentioned above will certainly have an influence on the nature and character of the person who does it. For example, a person who performs prayer because he is aware of the greatness and power of Allah, and is driven by feelings of gratitude and indebtedness to Him, will be far from bad deeds. Thus, his prayer will prevent him from doing bad deeds, in accordance with the word of Allah SWT:

"Indeed, prayer prohibits immorality and wrongdoing." (al-'Ankabut/29: 45)

Likewise with the ibadah of fasting. This ibadah will create feelings of love and compassion for the poor. Likewise, and so on with other ibadah. True ibadah is ibadah that is generated by belief in the greatness and power of Allah, and is driven by feelings of gratitude to Allah. Ibadah that is only because of following others, or because of maintaining traditions that have been passed down from generation to generation, is not true ibadah. Even though it seems like ibadah, it does not have the soul of ibadah. It is no different from a statue, no matter how similar it is to a human, it is not called a human. That kind of ibadah has no influence on nature and morals.

Striving, Praying and Trusting in Allah (Tawakal)

Isti'anah (seeking help) as mentioned above is specifically directed to Allah, meaning that no one has the right to be asked for help except Allah. In another verse, Allah commands humans to help one another in doing good.

Allah says:

"And cooperate in righteousness and piety." (al-Ma'idah/5: 2)

Is there a Contradiction between the Two Verses?

The achievement of a purpose, or the successful implementation of a job, depends on the fulfillment of the conditions needed in carrying out that job, and the absence of obstacles that hinder it. Humans have been given potential by Allah, both in the form of thought and physical strength, so that they can fulfill the conditions or reject obstacles in pursuing a purpose, or carrying out a job. However, there are some of these conditions that humans do not have the power to fulfill. In addition, there are also obstacles that they are unable to reject. Likewise, there are some of these conditions or among these obstacles that cannot be known.

Even though according to the mind all the necessary conditions have been met, and all the obstacles that hinder have been successfully overcome, sometimes the results of the work are not as expected. There are things that are beyond the limits of human power and ability. That is what is specifically asked for help from Allah. Preferably, something that is still within the limits of power and ability, humans are told to help each other, so that each individual has the characteristics of mutual love, respect, and cooperation.

In other words, humans are told by Allah to strive with all their might, and are told to help and assist each other. In addition to carrying out ikhtiar (effort) and striving, he must also pray, asking for taufik (divine guidance), hidayah (guidance) and ma'unah (help). This should be asked specifically to Allah, because only He has the power to give it. After all that, then he puts his trust in Him (tawakal).

Ibadah itself is a difficult task, therefore ma'unah must be asked from Allah so that all ibadah is carried out in accordance with what is intended by religion. Therefore, a person should say that only to Allah do we worship, followed by the statement that only to Him do we ask for help, especially help so that acts of worship are carried out as they should be. The verse above, as has been mentioned, contains tawhid, because worshiping solely to Allah and asking for ma'unah specifically to Him, is the essence of religion, and the perfection of tawhid.
text.6:
Ihdi: guide, show, give guidance (hidayah). The meaning of "hidayah" is to show a path or way to convey a person to their destination, in a good manner.

Types of Guidance (Petunjuk/Hidayah)

Allah has given humans various kinds of guidance, as also discussed in Tafsir Al-Fatihah by Muhammad Abduh.

1. Instinctual Guidance (Garizah)

Humans, as well as animals, are equipped by Allah with various traits that arise not from learning, nor from experience, but are brought from their mother's womb. These traits are called "instincts," in Arabic called *garizah*. For example, the instinct to "preserve oneself" (to maintain life). A baby cries when it feels hungry. After feeling its mother's nipple on its lips, it sucks until its hunger disappears. This action is done without anyone teaching it, nor does it arise from experience, but solely from inspiration and guidance from Allah to it, to maintain its life.

Another example is bees making their hives, spiders making their webs, ants making their holes and storing food in those holes. All of this is done by these animals to maintain their lives and preserve themselves, solely through the prompting of their instincts. There are many other instincts, for example, the feeling of "wanting to know," "wanting to possess," "wanting to compete," "wanting to play," "wanting to imitate," "fear," and others.

Characteristics of Instincts

Instincts (*garizah*), as mentioned, are found in humans and animals. The difference is that human instincts can receive education and improvement, but animal instincts cannot. That is why humans can advance, while animals do not; they remain as they were.

These instincts are the basis for goodness, and also the basis for evil. For example, the instinct to "preserve oneself" leads people to work, trade, farm, meaning to seek a livelihood in a halal way. Conversely, because of the instinct to "preserve oneself," people steal, deceive, rob, and so on. Because of the instinct to "want to know," people learn, so they possess much knowledge and high education. Conversely, because of the instinct to "want to know," people like to seek out the faults and secrets of their fellow humans, which results in enmity and disputes. And so on with other instincts.

These instincts cannot be eliminated, and there is no benefit in killing them. There are thinkers and educators who want to extinguish instincts because they see the bad (evil) side of them. Therefore, they create various rules to restrict the freedom of children so that these instincts do not grow, or those that have grown become dead. But their actions are very dangerous to the growth of children's minds, bodies, and morals. No matter how hard one tries to kill an instinct, it will not die.

It may be that because of the severity of the pressure and the strength of the obstacles against an instinct, it appears to have been extinguished, but when something awakens it, it arises again. Therefore, even though instinct is the basis for goodness, as it is also the basis for evil, the obligation of humans is not to eliminate it, but to educate and train it, so that it can be utilized and channeled in a good direction.

Allah has bestowed upon humans various instincts to be guidance (*hidayah*) that they will use wisely.

2. Guidance of the Senses

Because instinct is inherently uncertain, as mentioned above, it is not sufficient to be guidance for the happiness of human life in this world and the hereafter. Therefore, humans are further equipped by Allah SWT with the five senses. The five senses play a very large role in the growth of the human mind and intellect. In connection with this, education experts say:

(The five senses are the doors of knowledge).

The meaning is: it is through the five senses that humans can connect with the surrounding environment, in the sense that something from this surrounding environment reaches the human brain through the doors of the five senses. But instinct plus the five senses is also not sufficient to be the basis of human happiness. There are many things in this world that cannot be seen by the eyes. There are many kinds of sounds that cannot be heard by the ears. In fact, apart from the *alam mahsusat* (that which can be captured by the five senses), there is also the *alam ma'qulat* (that which can only be captured by the intellect).

The sense of sight (eyes) can only capture the *alam mahsusat*, and its capture of the *alam mahsusat* is not always correct; sometimes it is wrong. This is what is called in psychology "optical illusion," in Arabic called *khida' an-nadhar*. Therefore, humans still need other guidance. So Allah bestows the third guidance, namely "guidance of the intellect."

3. Guidance of the Intellect (Mind)

a. The Intellect and its Capacity

With the intellect, humans can channel instincts in a good direction, so that instinct becomes a source of goodness, and humans can correct the errors of their senses, distinguishing between bad and good. The intellect is even capable of arranging premises to lead to a conclusion, connecting cause and effect, using the *mahsusat* as a ladder to the *ma'qulat*, using what can be seen, touched, and felt to reach the abstract, the meaningful, and the unseen, taking evidence from the existence of creation to establish the existence of the Creator, and so on.

But the human intellect is also not sufficient to bring it to the happiness of life in this world and the hereafter, in addition to the various instincts and senses. Moreover, the opinions of the intellect vary; what is good according to the mind of A is not necessarily good according to the view of B. In fact, many humans use their intellect, but their intellect is defeated by their desires and sentiments, so that what is bad becomes good in their view, and what is good becomes bad.

Thus, it is clear that instinct plus the five senses, and plus the intellect, is not sufficient to be the guidance that will convey humans to the happiness of physical and spiritual life, in this world and the hereafter. Therefore, humans need other guidance, in addition to the five senses and their intellect, namely the guidance of religion brought by the messengers *'alaihimus-salatu was-salam*.

b. The Seed of Religion and the Creed of Tawhid in the Human Soul

If we look at the religions and beliefs created by humans (*al-adyan al-wadh'iyyah*), it is seen that in the human soul there are already seeds of religious inclination. This is because humans have the characteristic of feeling indebted, liking to be grateful, and repaying kindness to those who do good to them. So, when they observe themselves and the world around them, for example, the bread they eat, the plants they plant, the livestock they herd, the sun that radiates its light, the rain that falls from the sky that grows plants, they will feel indebted to "a unseen Being" who has done good and bestowed great blessings upon them.

Humans understand with their intellect that this unseen Being is the one who created them, who bestowed upon them and upon the human race as a whole, everything they need that exists in this world, to preserve themselves and maintain their lives. Because they feel indebted to an unseen Being, they think about how to be grateful and repay that kindness, or in other words, how to "worship that unseen Being."

The matter of how to worship the unseen Being is a difficult problem that cannot be achieved by the human intellect. Therefore, in history, there has never been uniformity in this matter. In fact, the human intellect will lead them to the belief of glorifying nature alongside glorifying the unseen Being.

Because their thinking is still simple and it has not yet been pictured in their brains how to worship the "unseen Being," they choose from among this world something that is large, beautiful, beneficial, or something they fear to be a symbol for that unseen Being. When they admire the sun, moon, and stars, rivers, animals, and so on, they worship these things as a symbol of worshiping God or the unseen Being, and they create ways of worshiping these things.

In this way, a kind of belief arises, which is called "the belief in worshiping the forces of nature," as found in Egypt, Chaldea, Babylon, Assyria, and in other places in ancient times. With this explanation, it appears that humans, according to their fitrah, tend to be religious, often thinking about where this world comes from, and where it returns to.

If humans want to think: "Where does this world come from?" they will arrive at a belief in the existence of God, even to the belief in the oneness of God (tawhid), because the creed (belief) in the oneness of God is easier and faster to understand by the human intellect. Therefore, we can affirm that humans, according to their instincts, are monotheistic.

History has explained that the Chaldean nation was originally monotheistic, then they worshiped the sun, planets, and stars, which they symbolized with statues. After King Nimrod died, they deified and worshiped Nimrod. The Assyrian nation was also originally monotheistic, then they forgot the creed of tawhid and associated partners with God with animals, and this is what was inherited by the Babylonians.

As for the Egyptian nation, if we pay attention to the songs they sang in worship ceremonies, it is clear that not all ancient Egyptians were polytheists and *watsani* (idol worshipers), but among them there were also *muwahhidin*, adherents of the creed of tawhid. In these songs, there are expressions such as the following:

"He is the One God, who has no partners."

"He loves all creatures, while He Himself was not created by anyone."

"He is the Most Great God, Owner of the heavens and the earth, Creator of all creatures."

It can be affirmed that this creed of tawhid has never disappeared completely and remains. The One God is the creator of all that exists in this world. The other gods or deities they consider to be only helpers and servants or symbols for the One.

c. The Opinion of the Arabs before Islam about the Khalik (Creator)

If the Arabs before the coming of Islam were asked, "Who made the heavens and the earth?" They would answer, "Allah." If asked, "Did al-Lata and al-Uzza make anything that exists in this world?" They would answer, "No!" They worshiped these deities only to hope for intercession and *syafaat* from them towards the real God. Allah says about the words of the Arab polytheists:

"We do not worship them except that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position." (az-Zumar/39: 3)

d. Belief in the Hereafter Can Be Achieved by the Intellect

When humans think about "where does this world return to?" they will arrive at the belief that beyond life in this fleeting world, there will be life in the hereafter that is eternal and everlasting. But can humans, with their intellect and mind alone, know what needs to be done or avoided as preparation for happiness in the hereafter? The answer is, "Of course not; history has proven this."

Thus, it can be concluded that humans have been given intellect by Allah to be guidance for them, in addition to instinct and the five senses. But the guidance of the intellect is not sufficient for the happiness of their lives in this world and the hereafter.

Likewise, humans have a nature that likes religion; with their intellect, they have sometimes reached tawhid. But the tawhid that they have achieved with their intellect often becomes blurred and impure.

By using their intellect, humans can also reach the conclusion about the existence of the hereafter, but the guidance of the intellect is not sufficient for the happiness of their lives in this world and the hereafter. So, to convey humans to a pure creed of tawhid, which is not mixed at all with beliefs of worshiping and glorifying other than Allah, to lay out the correct path that they will take in the journey of seeking the happiness of life in this world and the hereafter, and to be a guide in their lives in this world, they need other guidance in addition to the guidance that has been mentioned. So Allah brings the fourth guidance, namely "religion" brought by the messengers *'alaihimus-salatu was-salam*.

4. Guidance of Religion

a. The Main Principles of Divine Religion

Allah sent messengers to bring religion that would show humans the path they must take for their happiness in this world and the hereafter. The first thing that the messengers instilled was belief in the existence of the One God with all His attributes of perfection, to cleanse human beliefs from shirk (associating partners with Allah).

The messengers brought humans to belief in tawhid through intellect and logic, by using accurate and logical arguments. The dialogue between Prophet Ibrahim and Nimrod, Prophet Musa and Pharaoh, and the calls of the Qur'an to the Quraysh polytheists all invited them to use their intellect.

In addition to belief in the existence of the One God, the messengers also called for belief in the hereafter and the angels.

Belief in the existence of the One God with all His attributes of perfection, as well as the existence of angels and the Day of Judgment, is called *al-iman bi al-gaib* (belief in the unseen). That is the basis for all heavenly religions, meaning that all religions that come from God believe in the oneness of God, the angels, and the Day of Judgment.

In addition to the creed (belief) mentioned, the messengers also brought laws, regulations, morals, and lessons. These laws and regulations are not all the same, meaning that what was revealed to Prophet Ibrahim is not the same as what was revealed to Prophet Musa, and what was brought by Prophet Isa is not similar to what was brought by Prophet Muhammad SAW. This is because the laws and regulations must be in accordance with the circumstances of the place and time. So the sharia brought by the prophets is in accordance with their respective times. So what is different are the *hukum-hukum furu'* (branches of law), while the main principles of religious law, such as creed, are the same. Because Muhammad SAW is the final prophet, the sharia that he brought was given by Allah certain characteristics to be in accordance with all times and circumstances.

b. The Guidance Requested from God

Allah has bestowed the religion of Islam as the final guidance and weapon of life, or the path to ultimate happiness, but are all people good at using that weapon, and are all of Allah's servants successful in taking the path that has been laid out by God?

Many humans misapply religion, not worshiping (worshiping Allah) in accordance with what is pleasing to the one being worshiped, not implementing the sharia in accordance with what is intended by the maker of that sharia. Therefore, Allah teaches humans how to ask Him to be given *ma'unah*, to be guided and protected forever, and to be given *taufik* so that they can utilize all kinds of guidance that have been bestowed according to what is appropriate. Instincts so that they can be channeled in a good direction, the five senses so that they are correct, the intellect so that it is in accordance with what is true, the guidance of religion so that it can be implemented according to what is intended by the one who revealed that religion, without any defects, awkwardness, or errors.

In short, humans who have been given various kinds of guidance by Allah as mentioned above (instinct, the five senses, intellect, and religion) are not yet sufficient, but they still need *ma'unah* and guidance from Allah (namely His *taufik*). So it is that *ma'unah* and guidance that we ask for, and it is to Allah alone that we direct that request. In other words, Allah has given humans these guidances, as if He has laid out a highway that will convey humans to the happiness of worldly and hereafter life. Then what is requested from Him again is "to guide us in traversing the path that has been laid out."

In short, *hidayah* in the verse *ihdinas-siratal-mustaqim* means "*taufik*" (guidance), and it is *taufik* that is requested here from Allah. This *taufik* is requested from Allah after we have strived with all our strength, thought, and effort, because striving with all our strength is our obligation, but the success of an effort is within the power of Allah. With this, the connection of this verse with the previous verse is seen. In the previous verse, Allah teaches His servants to worship and ask for help from Him, while in this verse, Allah explains what will be requested and how to request it. So there is no contradiction between these two words of Allah and the word of Allah addressed to the Prophet:

And indeed, [O Muhammad], you guide to a straight path. (asy-Syura/42: 52).

Indeed, [O Muhammad], you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of the [rightly] guided. (al-Qasas/28: 56).

Because what is meant by *hidayah* in the first verse is to show the path that must be taken, and this is indeed the task of the prophet. What is meant by *hidayah* in the second verse is to guide humans in traversing that path and to give *taufik* so that they are successful and happy in their journey, and this is not within the power of the prophet, but is the right of Allah alone.

The Straight Path (that leads to the destination).

What is meant by the straight path? It has been explained above that the messengers have brought *aqa'id* (beliefs), laws, regulations, morals, and lessons. In short, the messengers have brought everything that is needed for the happiness of human life in this world and the hereafter.

So the *aqa'id*, laws, regulations, morals, and lessons are what is meant by the straight path, because it is what conveys humans to the happiness of life in this world and the hereafter as mentioned. So by mentioning this verse, it is as if we are asking Allah, "Guide us and give us *taufik*, O Allah, in implementing the teachings of our religion. Correct our beliefs. Guide us and give us *taufik* in implementing our beliefs. Guide us and give us *taufik* in implementing the laws, regulations, and lessons of our religion. Make us have noble morals, so that our lives are happy in this world and the hereafter."
text.7:
After Allah swt taught His servants to ask to always be guided to the straight and true path, in this verse Allah explains what the straight path is. Before the Qur'an was revealed, Allah had revealed His other holy books, and before the Prophet Muhammad was sent, Allah had sent messengers, because before the current ummah there were many previous ummahs.

Among those previous ummahs were prophets, *siddiqin* who truthfully and obediently confirmed the messengers, *syuhada'* who sacrificed their lives and wealth for the glory of Allah's religion, and righteous people who did good deeds and avoided Allah's prohibitions.

They are the ones who have been given blessings by Allah, and we are taught to ask Him to grant us *taufiq* and guidance as He has granted *taufiq* and guided them. This means that just as they were happy in *aqa'id*, in carrying out the laws and regulations of religion, and had noble morals and character, so too should we. In other words, Allah commands us to take examples and lessons from those who came before.

The question arises: why does Allah command us to follow the path of those who came before, when in our religion there are lessons, laws, and guidance that they did not have? The answer is: in reality, the religion of Allah is one. Even though there are differences, these differences are in the details, while the fundamentals are similar, as has been mentioned.

Just as in the previous ummahs there were people who were given blessings by Allah, there were also among them those who were cursed by Allah and those who were astray. Those who were cursed by Allah are those who refused to accept the call of Allah conveyed by the messengers, because it was different from their customs, or because it did not suit their desires, even though it was clear that what the messengers brought was true. Also included in this group are those who initially accepted what was conveyed by the messengers, but then for some reason turned away and turned their backs on the teachings brought by the messengers.

In history, many people who were cursed by Allah are found, since in the world they have been punished by Allah, as a fitting reward for their denial and arrogance. For example, the people of 'Ad and Thamud who were destroyed by Allah. Until now there are still traces of their remains in the Arabian Peninsula. Likewise, Pharaoh and his people who were destroyed by Allah in the Red Sea. Pharaoh's mummy is still stored in a museum in Egypt.

Those who are astray are those whose beliefs are not correct, or whose deeds and worship are not correct, and whose morals are corrupt. If a person's *akidah* is not correct, or his deeds and worship are wrong, and his morals are corrupt, woe to him, and if a nation is in such a situation, that nation will fall.

So with this verse, Allah teaches His servants to ask Him to be kept away from His wrath, and to avoid being led astray. It also implies Allah's command for humans to learn from the history of previous nations. How many events in history can be used as lessons and examples. In the Qur'an there are many verses relating to the stories of past ummahs and nations. Indeed, there is nothing that has a greater influence on the human soul than the examples of people and the comparisons found in stories and history.
